review:
This review is not intended to be technical. I'm sure you can find technical reviews on other websites or in Youtube. I purchased the galaxy Tab 2 exactly a month ago, but ended up returning it and waited for the Note. Wasn't that a smart move. The Tab just did not have it together. The screen was not very sensitive (compared to iPad and Asus brands), it was laggy, crashed several times, and the camera was laughable at best with no auto focus. PDF annotation was simply horrible. iPad and Asus tablets did a much better job annotating PDFs with the same capacitive pen than Tab.

Galaxy Note on the other hand is a solid tablet. The screen is very responsive. The S-Pen is just perfect; although, I still haven't figured out how to use the back eraser. I was afraid that resting my hand on the screen while taking notes would produce artifacts, but it did not. One thing that I hadn't tried with the Tab was the Peel Remote feature. I had a lot of fun controlling my TV and DVR with this app. It's a very interactive and fun way to watch TV. You won't go back to the DVR remote if you give this app a try. I don't know if other tablets have the remote feature, but if they don't, this feature alone is worth getting the galaxy for.

The back camera is 5MP, has a flash, and can auto focus. The Adobe Photoshop touch comes with some nice filters and many of the tools found in the actual software (Gradient, Fill & Stroke, Wrap, Camera Fill, Round corners, B&W, Color Replacement, Curves, Shadows/Highlights, Noise Reduction, etc). The S note app allows you to take notes or even write math equations. You can write down anything from simple algebra to differential equations and it will solve it by Wolfarm Mathematica in a side window! Pretty amazing. Oh yes, and the side window...is great.

Overall, I'm happy with this tablet. If you are deciding between this or the Tab or any other lower priced tablet, you should seriously consider the Note. It's indeed worth the extra $100.

I've been wanting an android based tablet (my wife has an ipad but it feels too limited for my use)to use for note taking for over a year now. I've tried a couple different tablets, acer a500/asus transformer and the capacative stylus just doesn't cut it. Heard about this at the beg. of the year and decided I'd get it, after a long delay which was to better the tablet, it came in yesterday. Though I know Windows Surface is supposed to be the end of Oct. and may be a game changer I've quite enjoyed my experience with android on mobile phones. Also, the app market being established and ease of sharing everything I have between devices is seamless.

I will update this review in a couple weeks, this is just an initial glance.

If you're familiar with a Honeycomb or ICS tablet then the Galaxy Note 10.1 should feel very familiar. Nothing new or exciting to write home about, TouchWiz adds a couple different bells and whistles (literally, the notification chime is a whistle which I actually like) but most of which I will not use. I'm used to stock android, Galaxy Nexus, so the extra fodder that TouchWiz provides doesn't do much for me. The 1st thing I did was delete all the pre-loaded widgets. I noticed that before I did this there was a slight delay scrolling, afterwards it seems fairly fluid. I currently only have my minimalist calendar and beautiful weathers widget loaded. I still feel that if it were vanilla ICS or Jelly Bean (eventually???) it would be lightning fast. But even still it is the most responsive android (and possibly apple) device that I've used to date.

The build quality was a little better than I expected, yes its typical Samsung plastic but it feels decently and has a good weight to it. I really like the greyish color as opposed to black and though the back panel is plastic it has a brushed metal look. The screen is bright and clear, despite everyones complaints about screen resolution, and is at least readable in direct sunlight - though not ideal. The bezel is near about the perfect size for a "writing" tablet if held in either portrait or landscape and the speakers give it a distinct look along with being very functional since they are forward facing. The screen is a fingerprint magnet like any other touch device, so I'll be looking at a non invasive screen protector eventually. Overal I give the build quality a 7.5 out of 10. Oh, and for those of you that care - after pulling teeth chatting with Samsung online they finally said the screen is indeed Corning Gorilla Glass, but I couldn't find anything legit online to back that statement up.

I've mainly been using the S Pen and am quite impressed. I think I'll finally have a writing solution instead of pen and paper. Nothing feels like ink to paper but this is pretty darned close. And being able to write small words, like I would on a pad, is great even though its hard to read my chicken scratch! But then again my penmanship is poor an paper....not much of a difference. The S Pen is the main selling point for this tablet and I think Samsung has a winner here. I give the S Pen a 9 out of 10

I think things can only improve and have a feeling we'll see an update in a couple weeks; with the hopes of Jelly Bean by the end of the year - Samsung hasn't been good at keeping update promises though. I really think that if people can get away from "screen resolution" this is the tablet to buy regardless if you want the S Pen. Though TouchWiz isn't as intrusive as I've seen in the past I'd still like to root this device and have stock ICS or Jelly Bean - it would no doubt blaze past Apple and anything else Android currently on the market.

I know this review was a little scattered and not detailed but I wanted to give a quick glimpse of what I thought, if you have any specific questions ask below and I'll check in periodically and answer them to the best of my knowledge.

UPDATE: 2/20/2013

OK - I've owned this tablet for about 6 months now, its time to give this review an update. I'll try to be as short and sweet as I can, but if anyone has any questions about something I left out please comment below or message me and I'll answer to the best of my ability.

I've changed my review from a 4 star to a 5 star review, and until a tablet comes on the market that I feel is better than the Note 10.1 at around the same price point it will remain a 5 star review, especially now with the 4.1.2 update.

This device is completely solid and functional. It is not like the vast majority of tablets that now flood the market and feel like an overgrown smartphone. The software is well implemented, multi-tasking is great, and the multi-view capability bring it very close to the feel of using a PC. I use it daily in the workplace and also at home, in which I now rarely even use my personal PC. The build quality is solid, I've dropped it several times and there isn't a scratch on it. (Though I do have a screen protector on it AND its in a cheap poetic case) But after using it this long and the abuse I give it daily, sometimes just throwing it in the passenger seat of my truck - I think the people who say the tablet is "cheap" feeling b/c of the plastic build do so unwarranted. If it were cheaply built I think mine would have already broken, the body or the internals.

It doesn't really matter if you are an Android fanboy or an iSheep, the fact remains that this is the best sub $500 tablet out there to date. It has a true filing system, is fast, has true multi-tasking, great screen, great battery life, great software and a solid build. Throw in the S Pen capabilities to those that use it and it is light-years ahead of the competition. I truly believe that anyone who wants a tablet for anything more than a facebook/email machine would be unwise to choose something else. But again.....just my opinion after using it for 6 months!

I didn't buy mine from Amazon as I couldn't find it on Amazon. I ended up going to my local BestBuy to pick it up. The reviews online were mostly okay except for The Verge which said it was sluggish and basically was down beat on it.

I decided to buy it and if I didn't like it I would be returning it. I picked it up around 5:30PM on the 16th of August which is the release date. The first thing I did was get rid of all the widgets that are on the home screens. I suspect those might slow it down. I kept only one widget which is the clock / weather widget. I then downloaded all my favorite apps and began to arrange and configure it the way I wanted it.

It comes with Polaris Office, which is better than QuickOffice if you plan to create and edit word docs, Polaris is easier. To view documents and complex excel sheets I find QuickOffice often does the better job. I ed up keep both installed just in case.

I installed 14 games on it. All of which perform very well. There are my favorites, like FieldRunners, and newer ones like Final Fantasy, Ski Safari, Nova 3, Osmos HD, Amazing Alex and Zynga poker that I also really like. This quad core eats through anything with ease.

Got the latest Google Maps, which is so fantastic on this. You can save a Map so it's available without a data connection. Perfect for these WiFi devices. I'm a fan of the new Google Play movies, music, books and Magazines too. But if you prefer Amazon or Nook, those are available as always. It comes with the B&N Nook Reader by default.

There are Galaxy Note 10.1 specific apps like Adobe's PS Touch. I've been using Photoshop since 1996 so I am going to carefully review the built in lessons for PS Touch, a mobile version of Photoshop and see how far I can take that. If you are a subscriber to Adobe's Cloud services you're supposed to be able to edit a PSD with PS Touch, save it to the cloud, and then continue to edit it with Photoshop the desktop app.

There is also S Note. S Note and PS Touch are geared to work well with the new Samsung Galaxy S Pen. This was a primary reason for me to be interested in this particular tablet. The S Pen is so accurate that you can hand write whole sheets of handwritten text with it. I didn't try to have it translated into actual text like type written text. I just left it as my handwriting. Really like it.

Now this new Note 10.1 also has a new Muli-tasking feature. I should say that it doesn't multitask any app combo you want. Just a few apps blessed by Samsung which are: The base browser, not Chrome, their video player, Polaris Office, the picture gallery and their email app, not the GMail email app. Their email app can be used with POP, IMAP and Microsoft's Exchange via the built in Active Sync. So I tend to use that email client for work email and I use GMail as my personal email client.

Now, according to The Verge, multitasking was horrible. Not so fast Verge. I don't know what you guys are doing but I multitask'd just about every way you can on this and it works surprising well. I wrote notes while playing video. I played video while scrolling up and down on a web page. I copied text from an email to S Note, which both apps loaded in the side by side both on the screen simultaneously method. I had no trouble at all.

I bought Autodesk's Sketchpad Pro and can draw with that just fine. I also bought Adobe Ideas, but haven't yet played with that at all. Samsung also has their own kind of store and I am going to see if they have more S Pen specific apps. Really like the S Pen a lot. It's exactly like a typical Wacom Stylus. It's sharp, not that horrible eraser head large stylus you get stuck with if you want to use a stylus on the iPad. Although the iPad has Paper by 53, which I wish I had on here.

I'm really just getting started. I'll have to update this review over the weekend. Only played with this new tab for about 4 to 6 hours now.

Check out Google's Currents for news, and Pocket for saving articles for future reading. Both are great on this tablet. I think all the bases are covered with this tablet. Movies, games, magazines, office and productivity, art creation and editing. It does everything. And since it is Android, you have a real file system which makes email a breeze. Love this thing so far.

Some quick first impressions of the Note 10.1 - This tablet is what the Transformer Prime should have been. I really don't see a ton of value in the S-Pen YET, but hopefully this feature will evolve and become a key strength.

General touch responsiveness - GOOD - scrolling home screens is much more responsive than the Galaxy Tab 2, very close to the responsiveness of the Transformer Prime.

Web Surfing - VERY GOOD - Page loads are very fast, much faster than the Galaxy Tab 2, very similar to ipad2 speeds. Scrolling is fast.

Screen - FAIRLY GOOD - Same screen as Galaxy Tab 2. Similar to ipad 2. Not as nice as the new higher resolution tablets.

I/O Performance - GREAT - RL Benchmark of 21 seconds... blows the doors off of ASUS & Nexus 7.

The Pen - UNDECIDED - For taking notes with OCR the S Note app does not seem like it will be able to keep up with a keyboard and Evernote. The app still seems a bit immature, hopefully will get better over time. Included S Pen does not have the eraser side seen in some online videos.

Gaming - VERY GOOD - Frame rates are fantastic, touch and accelerometer responsiveness seem great. HUGE improvement over G Tab 2.

Compass - Worked great. Seems very accurate.

WiFi - Seems to have strong reception and fast throughput throughout the house.

GPS - Strong reception, quickly got accuracy to 20 feet indoors.

Sound Quality - VERY GOOD - The front speakers are really nice for a tablet. You should have not issues covering the speakers with your hands.

Build Quality - GOOD - Nice fit and finish, no loose parts, no surprises. Still feels a bit plasticy, not as nice as ipad.

Software - Everything seems to run without any hiccups, more polished and less buggy than what I've seen on Asus tablets.

Let me know if there are any other aspects you'd like to get feedback on to help you make your decision on this tablet.

I've never purchased a tablet before, but as a grad student whose office had already been scolded for using too much toner (we're all first-semester Master's students as of Fall 2016) I figured that maybe it was time to invest in a product that would allow me to annotate my PDFs digitally. While I could probably do this with my computer, it's not the most portable device and I love the note-taking features my Samsung Galaxy Note 5 phone offers with its S pen, S Note, and Write on PDF features. Because I do a lot of reading, the phone's smaller screen wasn't suitable for a lot of late-night annotating, so when I went looking for tablets (on a budget, mind you, I certainly can't afford a Microsoft Surface Pro or anything), I knew that I essentially wanted a larger version of my Galaxy Note phone, and this tablet fits the bill perfectly, as the name would imply.

Because this version of the Samsung tablets is older, I couldn't download all the apps I have on my phone, namely the Microsoft Office Suite and Write on PDF functions, but I've found ways around both these obstacles. The tablet comes with its own suite of Microsoft Office-like products which I've found are passable for looking at (if not editing) Word Documents and because I mostly use Google Docs and Google Drive for writing papers and saving documents, this aspect hasn't really been an issue for me. The inability to install the Write on PDF app was a little more tricky to resolve because I use that app a lot on my phone, but ultimately after some searching I found an app that works even better: Xodo. This app lets you open multiple PDFs at the same time and switch between them with no problem, will read you passages out loud, lets you actually rotate weirdly scanned PDFs (all of which Write on PDF doesn't let you do), and does all the other things that the Write on PDF app does, so in some ways, I'm quite happy that I couldn't download my Write on PDF app.

All in all, while the tablet has the drawback of an older OS and an inability to download more recent versions of apps, it's a wonderful and affordable device (I bought mine for less than $200) and works fantastically for a grad student looking to take handwritten notes on it and watch Netflix. I would highly recommend this tablet and its S Pen to anyone looking for a tablet for note-taking or grad school purposes and who is on a budget.

I bought one 3 and a half years ago and it is still going strong, and is still my favorite tablet.  What makes it stand out?

1)  Front facing stereo speakers IN THE RIGHT LOCATION (unlike other tablets with front facing speakers).  Very good sound.
2)  Charging ports are the weakness of Android tablets/phones.  This is by far the most rugged and reliable charging port of any Android device I've used.  3.5 years without problems.  And I've been careful, but sometimes dropped it while charging.
3)  I'm no expert, but I believe Android 4 was the peak version.  Later versions don't really add much.  I like the look, functionality, and simplicity of Android 4 the best by far.
4)  The price now for this tablet refurbished is a steal.  Not worth the extra price for the 2014 version in my opinion.
5)  Display is excellent.  Great vs. viewing angle.  Brightness and color are fantastic.
6:  Good Samsung perks.  The Samsung keyboard is the best I've ever used.  Much better at predicting my next word than basic Android tablets.
7)  It is also reliable and rugged.  Top of the line speed in 2012, but still plenty fast today.

I purchased this tablet for nursing school, because I really liked the idea of being able to write notes and have them automatically saved to the cloud. Having had issues with losing notes in the past when I loaned them to classmates, it was a huge relief to be able to just email them to someone without having to give them up. The tablet's always been on the slow side, but it's an older model and it is refurbished so I really didn't mind much.
It worked great for almost six months. However, over this past weekend, I didn't have time to study and left my tablet on my desk the entire weekend. No one touched it, no one dropped it (single girl with no kids, so I know), and when I picked it up today, the colorization of the screen had gone negative and most of my programs are now illegible and unusable. I did some troubleshooting on my own to no avail (and no, negative coloration is not turned on under settings in case you're wondering), not even a hard factory reset fixed the problem.
I contacted Square Deals and was told that because I had gone past 90 days, they couldn't do anything. Not so much as a by your leave, or we're sorry, just a quick this is no longer under warranty email and that was that.
Rudeness aside, that's all well and good, I totally understand. But I spent over 200 dollars on a product that conked out on me in less than 6 months. If that's supposed to induce me to purchase another product from this company, they can think again. Ironically enough, I was actually planning on purchasing one of these tablets for my cousin's birthday as she is starting medical school soon. Still planning on it, but I am not going to buying one from Square Deals.
Bottom line: If you want to spend money on an electronic product that won't last, go for it. Otherwise, I'd stay clear and look elsewhere. Seriously.

After more than 2 years, the Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 has proven to be very reliable and durable. The glossy gorilla glass screen has not picked up any scratches, and the 802.11bg WiFi still connects instantly and remains associated to the AP. "I did not buy my device from Amazon". As someone who is a long time iPad user, this will my last time fooling with an android devices, especially this one. Here's why:
1. Not as easy & intuitive to use as an ipad
2. Big time batter drainer.
3. Can not use an sd card, thank to the KitKat update, so you basically stuck with your device internal memory.
4. Android updates are so slow reaching, and not every device gets the update at the same time, unlike apple OS.
5. Far less good apps.
6. Very hard to manipulate files and folders, need separate apps.
7. Bulky and heavy tablet

I know there are many hardcore android users out there who will not agree with me, but just take any of the above cons and try to convince someone who is new to android. Why would anyone in their right mind settle for slow-coming updates that some get and other don't? Or Why would any one to buy a device that advertise the use of an sd card when it can't be used?

I can go on and on, but these are just strong reasons not to buy this particular device, as well as all Android devices for those of you who are new to android. Buy and iPad and you will be very happy and far less frustrated.

Pros: It's light and feels good on the hands. The stylus is great with writing with the note app. it registers well with what you want to right and gives you the best ability to zoom and save space on each page you write on. Internet browsing is just like using your computer you just need to make sure you don't use the mobile websites and your set. Drawing is fun on here you can do so much with the photoshop and filters of the device. Camera is decent and has a good light adjustment function but that is it don't expect much out of it. the auto brightness function is awesome! It registers really well with your surroundings and helps save your battery life well. The batter life is amazing and gives you alot to work with when you are taking notes in class. If You have your WIFI off at all times your battery can last about three days without having to charge it. Keep this in mind though I had brightness below 50 percent and nothing running in the back ground of the device.

CONS: writing can be your worst nightmare if you don't have a cleaning cloth large enough to have your palm of your hand to rest on. I mean when I wrote in class I tend to rest my hand on the pieces of paper that I right on it just feels comfortable, but when I do that on the tablet there goes the page shrinking or enlarging as I write because I rest my hand on the screen. And you would think with a auto-locking function on the screen that keeps your hands from registering on there that it would work for you hand it sadly doesn't. The device will mistaken it for you trying to pinch the screen and trying to either enlarge the window or zoom out.

Verdict: 4/5 you get your money's worth if you use it for college work and you can really benefit from it actually being a ultra book like device which is really nice because you can almost do everything a computer can if you buy a keyboard. Losing the stylus means saying good bye to good note taking in class and spending 40 to 50 dollars on those little piece of turds. Be mindful that this is not a device to spend on for fun, if you want to get some solid work done like taking notes, reading slides, writing a word document , sending emails, or anything like making a planner then this will pay off greatly for you. If you want to look at cat videos or browse the internet of stupid things go spend your money somewhere else. I have been using this device on a daily basis and keep it well protected with a case. so keep in mind that a case is a must for this thing because it feels like i could step on it and break the thing in two.

I bought this because it was supposed to be better than the Tab2, 10.1 I already had, having a quad core processor and the stylus features. It came with ice cream sandwich os, and I ignored the update alerts for jellybean for a year or so while learning the features, but after reading the reviews and forums promising a "smoother" experience I gave in & allowed the update, the worst computing decision I ever made, and I'm so glad the tab2 still has the original ICS os, even tho it crashes regularly online, since at least it displays pictures well. Right after the Note update it was like a strange new environment of delays, pauses, glitches & problems. The Gallery ap was unrecognizable, and took forever to load, pictures moving in a circle is not worth waiting for. The latest problem is the my 32G micro SD is now unrecognized, so all my docs & pics are gone. I had a Samsung rep look at the Note & it took him 3 hours of tapping to free up a minimal amount of memory to eliminate the ever present low memory messages. I have no confidence in this machine and there being no way to revert to something that at least worked and I found useful, I'm now stuck with the industry standard never ending push toward planned obsolescence and the auto updating software Samsung/Google dictates I must sacrifice my memory for but never use. In my case progress is in the reverse direction and with no warranty remaining I now have essentially a $500 paperweight. I never attemped to root this machine or any other geeky stuff, all I wanted was a compact device to surf & do email.

Would I buy another Samsung? Take a guess...

This is a decent 10" tablet. It may be outdated at this point but still holds up for entertainment, games, and web browsing. The TFT display is almost as good as IPS, as Samsung knows how to make a good display. The front facing speakers provide excellent sound. It also has an active digitizer for added productivity. I bought one used for ~$225 dollars and I have no complaints, other than I learned that 8" tablets are probably a much better form factor. 10" is just too big.

I would only recommend buying this if you can get it used or refurbished on the cheap. It is not worth paying $400-500 for, as there are certainly more state of the art options in that price range these days. That said, it's a completely adequate and serviceable 10" tablet with the added benefit of a cool active digitizer stylus function.

One year after purchase... The tabs are still running perfectly. I bought both for my sons birthdays a year ago, and ordered two 8" tablets this year since their 10.1" notes worked out so well. I wish I had purchased the 32gb versions is the only regret. I spend a lot of time making room for new games at times. I rooted both tabs and run CM11 Unofficial for N8013. Using Philz Touch recovery. Cyanogenmod really makes use of the 2gb of ram by freeing it up for games instead of stock background processes. At 2gb Ram, these tabs still have more than most Android devices available. A funny thing is that even one year later, $180 each is still an excellent price! Hopefully the new tabs work out as well as these two have!

A very VERY nice buy on two of these tablets. $180 each... No charger or s-pen. I just bought them separately lol. Tablets were listed 'good' condition, but one should have been 'Acceptable' really IMO. The other was closer to 'Very Good' though. This is based solely on scuffs on the sides and back of the tablet. I still would have bought both though, and neither had a smudge even on the screen and both have perfect functionality. The folio case cover cover all but the screen anyway... So who cares! I should have bought the third one the seller had for a spare/backup device for my kids. These two were for my sons, ages 5 & 6. They already have Galaxy S4's and Tab 3 8.0's each and wanted a big tablet like I got their sister. I flashed CWM Recovery the CyanogenMod 11.0 with Android 4.4.3 KitKat and used Titanium Back to move a bunch of games from their phones/tablets over to these so they wouldn't need to start from the beginning. Freed up a lot of storage and put in a 128gb microsd with vfat format and a lot of games for emulators... very happy kids this morning! Thanks for the awesome deals on the tablets to the seller. Highly recommend this seller!

The Galaxy Note 10 has been a good investment for me.  My laptop crashed and I was faced with the expense of repair and or replacement and decided that I really didn't need the power of a laptop as much as I had thought and the number of apps available today for the tablet makes it a much more viable replacement computing device.  If you couple the size and weight issues in your decision process it is hard to say that the smaller unit is not the better choice.  As it turns out, the replacement of the HD for my laptop would cost as much as the Galaxy Note and I would still go through all the pains of reloading the computer. So I decided to give the unit a try, it has been great and I was right I hardly have missed the added power the laptop provides. I have access to all my files and the ability to bring them up, print them, or use them while in a meeting.  In many ways it is much more efficient even though less powerful. I did find, after the fact, that the note 10 does not support a SIMMs card and I was required to purchase a Hotspot in order to have an assured data link but that too has not been that great of an added cost and it is convenient.  My Samsung S5 has the wifi call option and now even in poor signal areas I just use the hotspot and all is well.  I have found the Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 to be very efficient and a viable workaround for a laptop.  I would recommend it to a friend.

I bought this for school. I researched a bunch of tablets, and everything said this was a pretty strong tablet with really good note-taking abilities (I should hope so, it's called the NOTE). It really is pretty awesome. You can write math equations into the note app and it'll solve them, same with chemistry symbols, and the pen feature works really well. Much better than I've found in a few others I tested out.

I really love my Galaxy Note, especially the S Pen function for taking notes is cool. I also use it to read at lot on the train, both pdfs for school and books on Kindle and I'm quite satisfied with the resolution, though the screen reflects quite a lot in strong sunlight. For me the two major drawbacks are that it takes very long to recharge the battery, about the same time as getting them empty, and while charging, you cannot use it. Or if you try to use it, it doesn't charge properly. The second drawback for me is (as I only have the Wifi model, so I can only access the internet via the hotspot on my mobile) that there is no USB port for quick download/upload of data for when I do not have a fast internet connection. When I first unwrapped it I could not believe it didn't have a USB port. You can buy an additional adapter but even so sometimes it would not recognize the device when I connected a USB stick. I don't want to be nit-picky, but for me these two drawbacks really detract from the otherwise great usability of the Galaxy Note

I decided to give the opportunity to samsung instead of apple, and the truth is that I have not disappointed. What is certain is that for the ipad, there is a greater variety of applications for both writing and drawing, and taking notes. But I buy this tablet basically for the application of SNOTE. And well, after trying several apps, I must say that best for writing are: Quill, Write and Papyrus. (Write and Papyrus are free apps).

However, for ipad , there are better apps for drawing in general. In my case, I stick with LayerPaintHD, and Sketchbook, that both works with layers, "most important function", if you are an artist or are looking for a tablet to draw. Well, if that's the case, I must say that this tablet, works great for painting and sketching, is excellent in these two applications. The sensitivity of the pencil in Sketchbook is instantaneous , almost like a normal tablet PC. In other applications, there is a delay too minimal to perceive during writing. For Quill, there is no delay in writing, the response is immediate. Quill is just like inking in OneNote, almost the same feeling. In the case of Snote, there is a minimum delay, but does not affect the sensitivity of the writing; feels quite natural and fluid stroke.

I use Snote just for everything, but for the most, for sketch; It feels like a real writing paper. Also, you can change the background of the paper, for grid paper, school notebook paper etc.

In general, the tablet is fast. Navigation on internet is fast. Videos on youtube are just in amazing HD. The battery life is long if you adjust (power save on) and disables screen rotation, vibration, gps, bluetooth and wifi. Screen colors feels vivid and beautiful. You can change the screen mood to: dynamic, standard and movie. Also, you can change the screen to negative colors which i like a lot by the way.

The only thing I consider negative, it's the size and shape of the pen. If you're an artist, you will notice this, and later you will want to buy another larger stylus. The size of the spen it's about 4.6 inches, in comparison of a regular wacom tablet pen, of 6 inches. For me, the size is too short for my big hand, and sometimes, at several minutes of drawing, it may feels unconfortable, but it's not a big deal, it's just because i'm a maniac in this type of stuff. Also, the shape of the pen (isn't round) like the regular pens, it's an square shape.

Finally, i recommend this tablet for any artist or hobbyist, that looks for a drawing tablet, or for school stuff, mathematics, just for everything you can imagine. This is the best tablet at these days. :D!!!

I am writing this review using the handwriting recognition tool. I like the fact that this tablet can convert My chicken scratch into text as quickly as I can write it down. I've had this tablet for 2 months so I've had plenty of time to explore it inside out.

I've read other reviews that complained about the screen resolution. I'm a graphic artist and it is perfect for me. I've played with the updated 2014 version and while the display is brighter, and the interface is almost identical to the Note 3 (which I also own), this version is still a solid tablet, especially with the new lower price tag. So if you want to save a couple hundred dollars I would not count this tablet out.

The S pen is VERY Useful to me. It feels comfortable in my hand and is very responsive. I prefer its position at the bottom of the tablet to the upper right corner where the 2014 version has placed it. The s pen interface for this tablet is like the one Used in the Note 2. So if you own or have owned that phone, it will be very familiar to you.

The multi screen feature is ok, but I do prefer the 2014's updates which allows more programs. I have had several windows open at one time and noticed no visible lag. You can also resize the windows and move them around.

Touch Wiz is on top of Android and Works Seamlessly with it. I love that you can fully customize this device and truly make it your own.

This tablet is geared toward people who want to do more with their device than browse the internet and Stream movies. while I would not call this a Computer replacement, it has made my job easier with Polaris Office and PhotoShop preinstalled. It comes with 16 Gb of native storage, but Can be expanded by 64GB with a micro Sd card.

One thing that I love about Android devices is you're not stuck with one music or movie player. I have several movies in .avi format and have found an app that plays them perfectly and with the big screen and front facing Speakers with great Sound, it's just a great experience.

Bottom line, I give this a glowing review. I have a Samsung Laptop, Note 3, and now the note 10.1. Iexen have a Samsung refrigerator. I'm not a brand loyalist, they just happen to make devices that cater to my needs and are reliable.

One thing I do hate to read about in these Reviews is when they compare this tablet to the iPad. They pander to two different audiences.

Background on how I utilize this tablet:
I am a student and utilize this mainly for school work. So I utilize this tablet as a textbook (digital copies), powerpoint reader, checking email, note taking, and very simple web browsing. I do also use it to view videos and movies from time to time.

For those who are not very tech savy, I warn that these tablets are not to be compared to a laptop as they do not have the same processing power or abilities that laptops have and the same way you cannot compare a laptop to the same standards of that of a desktop.

Battery Power: 5/5
When I first purchased this tablet and plugged it in, the battery charging indicator confused me. When charging the battery will show a red X that appears on battery icon on the lower right hand corner. I use this tablet about 5-6 hours a day and I can usually go about 2-3 days without having to charge it. I had this tablet on standby mode, (the tablet is on, but the screen is off) and battery life lasted about 5-6 days.

Speakers: 5/5
Remember these are TABLET speakers they are not meant nor are they built to be able to project 7.1 dolby surround sound. Do NOT have extreme or ridiculous expectations from these speakers. However I give them 5/5 because they do project and the volume does go much higher then I suspected and are well designed for a tablet and it's intended purpose as a secondary media device.

Software: 3/5
This is where I have to unfortunately drop some points, while Samsung did an extremely good job on the overall software there are some simple things that I do not approve of in regards to the software.

My main complaints are:
- There is no sensitivity control for the S Pen. While the S Pen works well for me on S Note and whatever else, there is not way to actually control the sensitivity of what gets recorded, so often I run into the trouble of the S Pen recording marks that I do not intend especially when I am lifting the pen up.
- There is no way to register personal penmanship characters, I write my 0's and 1's much differently then most people and I'm sure others have their own little penmanship quirks too. For a tablet that raves about penmanship recognition, Samsung should have implemented a way for the tablet to recognize individual handwriting and allow customization for each individual user's penmanship styles.
- Inability to delete default apps. It is extremely annoying to me that it is not just only with this tablet but with most modern electronic devices that we purchase that all these ridiculous apps that I will never ever utilize have to take up memory space and I am not able to delete them.
- S Note, I place my S Note complaint with software because it is part of the software that interested me to buy this product. S Note should have a continuous scroll for note taking rather then having to repeatedly having to recreate a new page once I am done with the previous.
- Another S Note complaint is the inability to have the zoom option off, I often accidentally zoom in when I am utilizing this app and it is a pretty big annoyance.

What Samsung got right for the software:
- Pages, widgets, and apps are easy to create, move, and organize
- S Pen removal pop up menu, although I wish that this was more customizable and not just the built in apps it does come handy.
- Taskbar: The taskbar allows the user to maximize the functionality and usability of this tablet. The return icon allows users to quickly go back or undo previous actions, the homepage allows for quick access your main page of apps, and the task manager allows you to remove apps that are not being used quickly as well as allowing you to switch back and forth between apps. In addition the taskbar allows you to pin apps much like on a computer running windows OS yet neatly keeps them tucked away so that they don't interfere unless you actually need to open them. Quick setting options and full setting options are available to the bottom right of the tablet.

Screen: 5/5
If you want to view something in extreme detail go use a good TV screen or a good computer screen. I have no complaints here, 480p looks great on here and HD 720p and 1080p of course looks better. The screen size is prefect for reading digital text books for me. Although the screen is a little bright for the lowest setting for me, it's not too much of a big deal to cause a problem.

Memory:  5/5
16GB is quite enough for myself, if I need to increase memory size I can always get more by getting a microSD card.

Overall Performance: 5/5
There are no performance issues with this tablet. Apps run quickly and load quickly.

I received this tablet Jan 1st and I was amazed at how snappy and intuitive everything was..

Unfortunately this tablet has turned into junk in less than 2 months of use

1) The tablet starts off extremely snappy out of the box, but that quickly fades once you install anything other than the basic apps already installed on it(also note that the tablet comes with a simple game called "crayon physics" that, by default, is allowed to gather details off of your contact list when there is no reason for it to have that ability)

2) Even though your paying $400+ for this tablet, you still have an outdated and extremely vulnerable version of the Android OS installed (version 4.1.2), which allows people to gain full access to all of your tablets features and files. Also, this version has the taskbar pinned to the bottom of the tablet at all times. What does this mean for you? When you're using the tablet for what it's made and marketed for(taking notes), your hand will constantly open up new windows, back out of your current window, take screenshots,etc... All because someone at Samsung figured it'd be a smart idea to place a task bar where most people rest their hands when writing.

3) While using ANY app whatsoever, the tablet will periodically go into sleep mode and you have to unlock it again to wake it. This isn't caused by inactivity and appears to be a bug.

4) While my tablet connects to wifi just fine when using Samsungs built in Web browser, NO other app can get a network connection. Dropbox,Play Store,Maps,Kindle,etc... Not app OTHER THAN Samsung's web browser gets connection, not even Samsungs own built in app store.

Now since I managed to make it over 2 months with this, I can't return it to Amazon and have to return it to Samsung, which is probably going to result in them spending hours troubleshooting before they give me my refund.

I relied on this tablet to take most of my notes for work and class since I've had it, so now I need to worry about transferring all of my docs and notes over somewhere else temporarily while this gets sorted out...And this will probably take awhile..

- I can't copy large chunks of text from Polaris to other word processors, which is irritating when I'm writing.
- The autocorrect doesn't... well, autocorrect. It offers a likely alternative, but you have to actually hit it to make it fix your typos, which really slows down writing.

The tablet is great, other than taking 12 hours or more to charge the battery each time. Samsung has a problem and needs to step up to the plate and fix it. I bought this on Black Friday for the upcoming semester because I wanted to try taking notes differently rather than using paper. So far it's been pretty reliable, I take my notes in class, upload it to Google Drive, and access the notes through any computer with internet access. The S-Pen is amazing, it not too hard to write with and my handwriting looks pretty much the same compared to my normal writing, although as expected it is a little worse. The battery life is pretty good, I am able to last a school day which is around 8 hours taking notes (I don't use the tablet the whole day). The apps are fine because it has Google Play, and I don't really play games on this so i wouldn't know if it lags. I will list some of my favorite pros and some of the things i do not like:

Pros:
- Can Open two apps at once. THIS is extremely useful for students who want to take notes and access the calculator or Internet, or even the everyday person who wants to multitask. I think the iPad doesn't do this so it is at a huge disadvantage.
- Google Play Store
-S-pen. I see other college students type their notes on the iPad, which to me looks time-consuming and it's harder to draw pictures or formulas or write something that would be difficult with a keyboard.
-Lightweight. It's 10 inches but it is still easy to carry.
-Ability to upload notes to Google Drive. I love this because Google is so convenient and I can access my notes and print it out through a school printer.

Cons:
-I wish I could write on pdf's or word documents. Maybe there is a way, but I didn't find out yet. SEE BELOW.
-The screen froze on me once already. Hopefully it doesn't happen again but it's less than 4 months and it doesn't look good if that happens, especially when I need it during class.

EDIT: I found that you can download PDF's and import them into S-Note, which is very useful because you can just write on the professor's PDF's, Word Docs or Powerpoints without making a seperate note. I really like that feature. Also another thing I did not mention is that when you write on the bottom of the screen, you are prone to touching the settings option by accident which happened to me numerous times. I'm not sure how to fix it but it get's annoying.
Great buy for its price! I recommend this product to tablet shoppers out there.. The interface is good and I like how sleek it looks.

I was looking for a tablet to use for college as several of my classes either required or highly recommended a tablet over a laptop for note taking during clinical. My first thought was, as it is for most people, to look into the iPad. Since I have a galaxy phone, I figured it would probably be easier to stick with the same OS so as not to have to buy new apps and start all over. I was glad I did because I came across the Galaxy Note and couldn't be happier with it.

Why I love it:

-The price: I got it during a lightning deal and paid WAY less than I thought I would for a tablet of this size and specs. As any college student will tell you, saving money wherever you can is a huge plus

-The size: I love the 10.1" display, the resolution is great and while it may not be quite as nice as the iPad Retina display, it looks great for movies, games, and of course school work. The tablet itself is pretty thin and easy to hold for extended use.

-S Pen: My main use for this tablet is for taking notes and studying, and the S Pen makes this tablet perfect for that. Normal tablets use stylus that make your handwriting illegible because of the big eraser like tip, but the S Pen allows for fine, pressure sensitive writing that looks and feels just like writing on paper. It also works great for drawing/photo editing if you're into that.

-Front Facing Speakers- Im not sure why, but a lot of tablet manufacturers **cough cough-Apple-cough cough** have really neglected peoples desire for front facing speakers. To me it just makes sense that when ever you listen to music or watch videos your looking at the screen so dual front facing speakers like the Galaxy Note's just seem to make sense.

-The OS/Apps: Coming from a Galaxy phone I like the set up, but I also want to give a shout out to two included free apps, S Note and Photoshop Touch. S Note is great for taking notes and comes with tons of great features (really good for students) and Photoshop is a whole lot of fun to play around with, even is you have no experience with PS. Google Play has tons of apps to download or sideload so you'll be set with tons of options

The One (and only) Thing I Do Not like about it:

-The charging cord: This version of the Note uses a proprietary  charging/data cord (included), but it would be nice if it used the standard micro usb as the galaxy phones and many other smart phones. On that note, I believe the 2014 version uses the micro usb cord.

Bottom word: Get this tablet! I use it everyday and have never regretted purchasing it. Its a great tablet for the price, a lot of fun, and great for school work, business use or just for fun. Hope you enjoy it as much as I have.
This tablet does everything I wanted in a compact device that has a great video quality and features.  Speakers are a little weak but I use it with earbuds most of the time anyway.

I truly love this tablet, I really do. I have a Galaxy S3, so I immediately decided a Samsung tablet would be what I purchased. I would not, however, pay $400 for it (I bought it on a lightning deal for around $340) for a few reasons.

No home button - I didn't think this would bother me. Turns out, it does, and I'm glad it's something they included with the 2014 edition. If the screen goes dead, you have to press the power button, and since I have a lock on my tablet, I have to go through that again. If an app freezes (which happens occasionally, but not often) you have to use the power button instead of having a button to return you to the home screen. This is my biggest issue with this tablet.

S-Pen is lacking a feature I would have liked, which would be to turn off sensing my fingers/hands/skin. I bought this tablet for note taking and drawing, but it's almost a chore because the screen constantly skips around when I try to use the S-Pen with it because my hand or wrist rests on the tablet as well. It's annoying. I know some app's allow you to turn off the sensitivity, but I shouldn't have to pay $4.99 for something to do what my tablet should.

No swype. I know, I know. It's a tablet. But sometimes I just want to use swype when holding the tablet vertically. Swype isn't installed, and you have to buy the app. Doesn't work for me.

Those are pretty much my only flaws. I do love this tablet and I don't regret purchasing it at all.

I am currently a college student and have been looking for the perfect note taking tablet. I am currently very happy with my choice. The s note taking app is perfect because it allows me to handwrite, type my notes or even use it's handwriting recognition feature to jot down notes. Adding pictures to the notes is as simple as pushing an icon button in the top right hand corner. The s pen is comfortable and is obviously an extension of the tablet. The galaxy knows when the s pen leaves the tablet, giving you a notification and opening up a side bar full of apps they utilize the pen for quick note taking. It even knows when the pen is hovering over the screen. A tiny dot appears when hovering and when placed on top of icons, will give a description of the icons function. This little dot is also great for editing messages due to its precision. This tablet runs very smoothly and has access to the full droid app store. I absolutely love this tablet and can't wait for classes to start do I can start using it.

The tablet is incredibly versatile. I can use the many apps available on the play store for personal activities as well as work tasks. I managed to set up this tablet using a few productivity apps for work and the apps cost me nothing.

Pros: Huge number of apps available on play store that are built for tablet use. Long battery life. Awesome screen allows for great graphics. Love the fact that I can increase the storage space for very little money.

Cons: Not quite as responsive as I would like. Web pages load quickly but not as quickly as other devices. I have used the built in browser as well as Chrome and Firefox. Apps can sometimes take a couple seconds to render.

I would recomend this product to anyone that's in the market for a tablet but doesn't want to spend a huge amount of money.

I received this tablet as a gift for my birthday. Im pleased with it for the most part but there are things that really irritate me about this tablet. Here they are:

1. The microphone for the tablet is located at the bottom where the charging port is. Very annoying. When I skype with friends and family they tell me that my voice sounds "muffled". The only way they can hear me clearly is if I hold the tablet, which brings me to my next problem.

2. I bought a little case for the tablet which props it up so I don't have to hold it. I really love the case but when the tablet sits up right the microphone is covered. When it lays flat no one can see me. When I turn it sideways so it is in portrait mode the person in which I am skyping cuts in half. I don't know if that is a tablet thing or a skype app thing but the tablet doesnt adjust to the change. When it is upside down (camera at the bottom, microphone at the top) it works but then whoever im skyping with is practically looking up my nose. I don't like it.

3. The battery runs down even when Im not using it. When I had my ipad I could turn it off and leave it for a couple of days and the battery would barely go down. This tablet acts more like a computer (I have to shut it down every night or when I'm not using it)

4. The tablet comes preloaded with roughly 1GB of apps I DONT WANT!! There is no way to delete them unless you "root" your tablet (I looked on YouTube for how to do it and it's a process. Not to mention the damage that could be caused if a mistake is made)

5. I specifically wanted this tablet because I thought it would be very useful for school (I'm a junior in college). I really like taking notes my tablet but I'm irritated by the lack of printing options. There aren't any! When I tried to print my boarding pass it gave me an error saying "Can only print using a Samsung Printer". Seriously??? This tablet brand new costs almost as much as a new ipad and I'm restricted to only using a Samsung printer? I'm very unhappy about that.

6. When watching a review about the tablet I saw that you can hand gesture and the keyboard splits in half. I can't get mine to do it. I have tried over and over. It just doesn't work for me.

In the long run I like the tablet. I'm not a very picky person and I can look past these defects since it was a gift. I would have definitely given it 5 stars if it weren't for those tablet manufacturing errors. I personally wouldnt drop $400+ of my own money on it but since it was a gift Im okay with it.
Look exactly like the seller described it, the size the color and everything would have given him five stat if it comes with ear phone)
I love my new tablet. We are inseperable,since i am at Work all day this is the only way of communication with my family.

This is really a 4.5 star rating. I've had this tablet for over a year, so it's gotten a full workout. The primary uses for me are keeping a hand-written journal and use as a portable art pad, so having a wacom pen, the same technology I use at my desktop for professional graphics work, was a must. Then Wacom came out with their own pen for the Galaxy Note, the Bamboo Feel. It's full size, more responsive, looks and feels great in the hand, and I use it most of the time.

I started the journal using Samsung's S-note app but had problems saving files--some files disappeared for reasons I still have not discovered, and I lost about six weeks of journal, hence the half star deduction from the rating. I solved that issue by exporting every day's entries to Dropbox as both .snb and PDF files. Eventually, I switched to using Papyrus, a vector based app that allows for a thinner pen line than S-note's thinnest .5mm. Papyrus also allows export to PDF, but because it's vector-based, it's a cleaner file that prints more crisply than S-note's jpg PDF export. I can also open a Papyrus PDF page in Adobe Illustrator on my desktop for further modification of the vectors beyond what can be done in Papyrus.

For artwork I like the Sketchbook Pro app best. It has an abundance of brushes and allows layers. It also can export a PSD file that keeps the layers intact so further work can be done in PhotoShop or Painter on my desktop.

At first I was concerned about the screen resolution, but it's very sharp and bright and has not been an issue. It's good to see that the new model has doubled the resolution, but this will do fine for a few years before upgrading.

All in all, I'm very pleased with this tablet. If your needs are similar to mine, I'm sure you will be too.

Let's get the cons out of the way b/c I'm sure that's #1 priority

Cons

1) Icon text and system text are not clear. Also small text looks like they suffer massive pixel shortage (which is not true).

BUT texts are incredibly clear and legible when reading books or watching caption on video, or viewing normal/large/larger text on the website. If you compare those activities with one of those $500 tablets like Ipad Air, Note 2014 or Lumia 2025, they all look the same.

2) Awkward positions for control buttons.

For example, if you use a tablet case and lay your tablet horizontally, the volume, headphone input, and power buttons will be on the bottom. In other words, you can't use your headphone (unless u flip it the other way), adjust your volume, or turn off/on the screen unless you have to lift up your tablet.

3) Proprietary charging/data sync cable. It is not the standard USB micro. It is the Samsung 30 pin or something cable.

Pros

1) Battery life is longer than the Note 8. I was able to watch movies for more than 4 hours straight.

2) Not heavy at all considering it weighs 650 grams.

3) Responsive and fast for an old processor. I did not notice any lag when switching between apps or playing game, movies.

4) S-Pen is great (don't use the S-pen apps, they are ineffective and inefficient at best). You have to buy the 8 PI S pen to truly appreciate the accuracy of the pen though. The included S-pen is only 6 pi.

5) No real buttons. You navigate the tablet using the on-screen buttons. This is incredibly helpful when using with the S-pen and everything else. It really helps you when you are holding the tablet too.

Conclusion

- I feel that this tablet has so much potential if it wasn't for Samsung failed on the S-pen app and the awkward positions of the volume, power, microphone input buttons. In addition, for some reason the text clarity of the system icon and small texts are garbled. This does not make a good impression on first time buyer especially when they they think a tablet is an Ipad.
Samsung had already come out with a 2nd generation Note when I purchased this device, but the quad core processor clearly beats most of the other tablets including the newer Apple device.

I have changed tips from the rubber tip to the hard nylon type tip due to the rubber tip wearing out. I really wanted to like the Note - and don't get me wrong, it is a beautiful device, feels great to the touch and does anything your smartphone does on a bigger screen and a little bit more. It's easy to be swayed by the Note, but other than showing off and being happy about its entertainment value and beauty, it's a bit unnerving. Having to learn all its quirks and options (especially with the stylus) requires a long and steep learning curve, there are absolutely no instructions, so prepare for having to google for just about anything a bit more sophisticated you want to do. I had intended to use the Note for my office, to show movie clips to clients and to type notes. That's when things got complicated. While the calendar syncs with my Galaxy S3, Notes do not. And the pre-installed office app does not print to my Epson Workforce printer (it insists it can only print to a Samsung printer), requiring awkward work-arounds that got me really irritated. So, after I bought a 64 gig sd card and a Logitech bluetooth keyboard and a cover for the whole thing (we are now at almost $700), I suddenly realized that this is a lot of money for checking emails, watching Netflix and browsing the Internet. I returned the Note and all its accessories - for that kind of money, it needs to do more: offer a keyboard, a cover or sleeve, and allow to print to any printer (I believe since addressed with Android Kitkat). If you have money to spend and want a great looking toy with a brilliant screen and value entertainment over productivity, I say go for it. All others are better off with something else.
PROS: Beautiful, brilliant screen, great sound, lots of features, long battery life, plain fun to use
CONS: Hampered productivity, questionable usefulness of stylus, no instructions or manual, very expensive
RECOMMEND: For entertainment purposes absolutely, anything else is a more of an expensive joke really.

This is my first tablet. The stylus peaked my interest and it delivers. It can effectively take the plan of all the paper I forget to organize. the device is fast and it takes the place of most things I would do with an un plugged notebook.

That being said 4 stars means there is definite room for refinement.

S-Pen
*It fits in The device and its convenient. There are some uses for The button but not many. The scrapbooking app on the 2014 model should provide more functionality.
* The S-Pen "keyboard" is an option of the standard (and capable) Samsung keyboard. The downfall d- This strategy is it you choose to use a different QWERTY keyboard such as Minuum. Then Handwriting entry is far away.
* Speaking of Minuum, it has a feature that the Samsung script "Keyboard" could emulate. If you tap on any text, Minuum provides the same alternate words as when you typed. This is a very convenient editing feature given imperfect handwriting.

S-NOTE
This app has VERY promising features in terms of handwriting recognition and more specifically its ability to recognize handwritten math and recognize standard Euclidian shapes. Having said that its abilities for post-processing are lacking.
* far times when recording sheer speed of is necessary it would be nice for S-Note to record vectors and allow the user to go back later and do text recognition.
* Integration of text and graphics is less than perfect. If I was using MS-Word I can specify graphics to be in line with text so subsequent edits would not "reposition" the relative position of text and graphics.
* It's surprising that the Signature app for taking notes does not seem to take advantage of different pressure levels. Instead I have to thread through a popup menu to adjust par width and opacity. For that matter a menu be would be far more convenient with color choice as well.
* Export formats are sorely limited. Handwritten or type written that is recognize cannot be exported to ubiquitous docx format. This is unforgiveable. I have taken many Notes using S-Nole and when I want to categorize some scripting I was left with two horrible choices: cut & paste or export to Graphical PDF. ... lame... And that cost the 10.1 1 star.
* If Samsung would write drivers to make a note 10.1 work just like a Bamboo stylus tablet That would doubly justify the added cost of the Note. As of this writing someone has done just that ... for Linux. Stock capability would be nice for Windows and Mac.
* The page Size and amount of text you can fit is fairly small. Templates with smaller or 2 to 1 ledger lines would be nice.
* Finally S-Note would do well to take some organizational and input flow Cues from MS One note. Had windows mobile had any Significant app support I probably would have went in that direction despite owning a Note 2 which is jest a small version of the 10.1 with a phone.

Overall ... functional with Lots of potential. However of your net planning on taking lots of handwritten notes or using the sketching apps that take advantage of The integrated WACOM digitizer, yatto stick to the TAB or a Kindle Fire model that are well priced.

I was looking for an ideal tablet to take notes & rid myself of the tons of printing and barrage of papers I'd have to deal with in my law classes, which have a lot of pdfs of cases, articles, etc. I wanted to be able to annotate pdfs clearly and with ease. After researching a bit, I knew the Ipad and most tablets under $400 were out. Heavy note taking needs tablets that support a pressure sensitive, active stylus.  A tablet using an active stylus has a higher price tag than the average tablet, and that narrowed it down to the surface & Note 10.1. The high price of v the Surface led me to the Note.

Once you find the right combo of note and annotating apps, you do not at all miss old fashioned paper or a laptop for those tasks. Some highlights:

- S pen: the number one highlight of the Note is the S pen. It's like I'm practically writing with pen and paper.  I'm kind of a paper purist.  I had preferred writing my agenda in journals over Google calendar as of late,  but this is like the best of both worlds.  I get the freedom of blank pen and paper with the right note apps along with the advantages of digital storage so I'm not lugging around tons of papers and journals.

  -Multi window: This allows me to treat my tablet like a textbook and notepad in one-I put my readings on one side of the screen and place the note pad on the other. To do this you need apps that support the multi window function. The best to me are the lecture notes PDF viewer and a note app called Write. I cannot overstate the importance of this for class note taking. Without multi window, it'd be like placing your textbook on top of your notebook instead of having the notebook next to it, and every single time you want to write something,having to get the notebook from under your text book. Switching between windows is a headache and a time waster, so multiwindow resolves that. The s pen and multiwindow alone set the Note leaps and bounds above any $600 or less tablet you can find.

- handwriting to text function: though not perfect , it helps having a tablet that supports detailed handwriting as a replacement for keying in letters. I did some of this review with the handwrite to text feature, some with the stock swipe keyboard feature (which is superb) and the other with voice to text. It helps because I absolutely hate writing on virtual keyboards and these features do a pretty decent job with accuracy especially the swipe keyboard and voice to text.

- the Android system: because I use Google for so many of my everyday internet needs including Google Drive,Gmail, Google Calendar, Keep, and for searching, I want a device that seamlessly syncs all of those accounts. I bought this tablet for drawing on the go, and I have been very impressed. I use autodesk sketchbook pro *mobile edition* with my note, and it works pretty good with a few minor inconveniences.
I was on the fence about buying a tablet for years, and now I wonder how I ever lived without one. Break time at work is a pleasure now, and the longer I have my tablet the more I learn to love it!

WHAT IS THE NOTE 10.1, WHY BUY THIS TABLET AND NOT SOME OTHER?---

I have since used several tablets and can honestly say this tablet is a rockstar for its price point and what it can do, but only if you care about the drawing or painting. The S-pen is not like buying a kindle fire and some 3rd party pen. That sucks compared to what the Galaxy note can do.

Tablets that were not built with Wacom digitizer technology can not use pens with small fine point tips like the galaxy notes can. Those other tablets have to use ugly thick point tips that use a fragile material that will crack and peel away, or other strange pens with flat silicon transparent tips. I have heard a lot of artists gripe about how lousy these solutions are on various art forums, and I can see why.
With the note you get a nice fine point tip, with incredible precision, and much more pen tip durability.

THE S-PEN---

I use a Cintiq 22HD at home, and while obviously better for drawing, the note still holds up surprisingly well for drawing. The S pen isn't quite as good as an intuos and cintiq pen, but still the lines are extremely accurate on screen. The pressure sensitivity is decent though you may wish to adjust this. There is no cintiq\intuous style tilt support, but there is pressure sensitivity, which can be adjusted but requires opening the pen with a screw driver in a sorta awkward kind of way.

The pen button is my personal biggest disappointment, as I can't set it to do what I want in drawing apps like swap to eraser or undo. The included pen also has no eraser on the end, you have to buy a different pen for that, which does not fit in this devices' pen slot, so you have to carry it separate which kinda goes against the whole portability of this tablet thing, so I just manage with the included pen.

The pen as I mentioned earlier has a small tip unlike all them other ugly 3rd party pens you get with most all other tablets. The tip is silicon though, which produces more drag when drawing then what you are used to if you use an intuos or cintiq. Instead of feeling like easy to slide plastic on plastic or glass, you get a rubber on abrasive plastic kind of feel, so it takes more muscle to move the pen. This lends well to do careful thoughtful lines, but not as well for loose sketches. Even so it isn't horrible or anything. There are just days when I am in the mood for this silicon grip feel, and then days when I just want to loosely flick my pen across the canvas. Some people might be very bothered by this.

*EDIT*-- I have since learned that normally when you buy a note, they come with extra nibs. My refurbished note 10.1 only came with 1 nib that was in the stylus, and was the soft silicon type. I bought a stylus with an eraser to get the harder plastic nibs I really wanted and am now even happier with the S pen***

THE SCREEN---

I wasn't sure I would want such a large screen before buying, but after using this I can say for drawing that I would have been disappointed with the smaller samsung models. I feel 10 inches is about perfect compromise between portability and canvas size. It's just small enough to fit in my wide winter coat inside pouches, though most jackets probably won't have wide enough pouches to do this.

I have seen newer I-pads and such that have brilliant screens. The note clearly is not as high resolution, at least not this older model. The newer 2014 note 10.1's have a much improved resolution. Even so, these older and cheaper note 10.1's have "imo" a darn good screen that is more then high enough resolution for me. It still is a great looking screen compared to all the el' cheapo tablet brands.
The screen surface is very durable too, I haven't got a scratch yet after my months of use, whereas I've seen some cheap brand tablets with all kinds of screen damage.

The screen size is wonderful but you should know that you should ROOT this tablet! The navigation bar that is ALWAYS taking up screen space *even when it's not lit up, it's a black bar on the bottom hogging up screen space*, and ALWAYS getting in the way, because some genius decided to put it at the bottom instead of the top, and gave no options to move it is annoying. I would constantly hit this bar and do all sorts of things I didn't want to do, such as go back, or to the home page, or go into settings.
Rooting was easy but took a little reading up. There are plenty of free apps to let you remove the nav bar, or change how it works, or when it shows up. I personally use "fullscreen!".
I should also note that the nav bar thing is a common problem on many tablets using older versions of android.

THE POWER---
The 4 cores give this thing a fair bit of power. Swapping back and forth between apps is very fast. This thing multitasks pretty well. I commonly have sketchbook pro, music, and reference pictures up at the same time, and it clicks along just fine *though I have crashed it once or twice doing this heh*.

I can play 3d games like "angry birds go" very smoothly. I have yet to find a 3d game that my tablet can't handle, and very well too. There are more powerful tablets, but this thing is still playing the top of the line games available to tablets.

speaking of multitasking---
Some programs like the gallery, internet, or pdf files can work in dual window mode *push the pin tack on the windows to make it stay put when drawing* which is very helpful, since I like to put ref on 1 half my screen and have canvas on the other half for drawing practice. But again rooting helps here too with plenty of programs that require your tablet to be rooted, but can allow ANY program to work with the multi-window mode.

This tablet will burn through the battery at a reasonable rate *like 5 hours or less* if you have the brightness cranked up to 100%, and using the pen. I like having the brightness at 25% or less at night, and more like 50% at day, and so it definitely can go a few more additional hours when used like this. If you are new to tablets, know that changing brightness can be done on the fly *just click on the clock on the nav bar, and adjust the slider that is right there on the pop up menu*.

CONCLUSION--
This tablet is a blast. It runs 2d and 3d games very fluidly, and the large vibrant screen gives a good quality that will make just about any el cheapo tablet look bad, but won't impress your friends on newer more expensive tablets. The sound isn't half bad too with speakers on the front like all good tablets should have, but often don't. If you are not into drawing, I would probably recommend the galaxy tab 3 instead as a bargain tablet with power.

For people who like to draw or paint, I can't imagine anything being better except the two thousand dollar cintiq tablets. This is a wonderful entry level cintiq basically, and it is a computer too that you can take with you, that plays music, games, movies, open all them art books you should be studying from. There are a few days where I actually prefer my note for drawing over my cintiq, as it does have it's own unique, personal, and compact feel.

This tablet is not a joke for drawing, it's a wonderful draftsman's companion that feels like your own personal dairy and fully functional computer all in one, wonder device. Get sketchbook pro, it's like 5 bucks on mobile app stores, setup your double tap buttons on the corners for undo and clear canvas, put on some music, and have fun! The Galaxy Note 10.1 rocks!

I was one of those that scorned at the rising trend of tablets, thinking it unnecessary and show-off toys. But then my inner tech-geek started to yearn for one. They're small, they're easy to just stuff in your bag, brining with you loads of entertainment and utilities all the time. Being a university student I used to bring my Macbook to school for taking notes. It was heavy and clumsy.

Bringing the Note along is so easy and it doesn't weight anything. In fact, I never leave home without it now.

The primary use I had in mind for it was note-taking during lectures and classes. It offers a wide variety for doing so just with with the tools that is already installed on the tablet. You can freehand with the pen, you can have your handwriting translated into text, and you can write as if on a computer.

A bonus is that it offers a variety of drawing apps for when I get dead bored in school. Doodling is more fun, and so easy with the tablet!

It has become my saviour during my all-in-all 2 hour trip to school and back home. It's easy to just dig it out from your bag and start watching films, the screen is nice with good colours and clarity, or read a book. There is apps out there that's really good both for films and reading. I started to read solely on this tablet, abandoning my Sony e-reader because the tablet had better app-utilities for reading (stuff that the new Kindle Paperwhite have so I'm going to give that one a try now).

All in all, I use it far more than I ever thought I would, and to do various tasks and for enjoyment. The battery life is good and quite normal. When using it sparsely it lasts for days. When using it more heavily it can lasts for about 2 days with no problem.

It has given me my money's worth and I'm pleased with it.

This WHITE 10" Note that Amazon is selling has a single core processor.  The Deep Gray one has a quad-core.  You can see it on the Amazon website.  Click the WHITE color.  Note how the processor changes from quad to single core. Note also the change from Jelly Bean to Ice Cream Sandwich. I am reviewing the WHITE one but you will see this review under the Deep Gray model also. Same price.  $449.  If you want the white (bone) in a quad-core Samsung and New Egg both have it for $449.  Bone white looks very cool.

My strong advice.  Do not buy this single processor model.  Amazon should have the WHITE quad-core version of this most excellent tablet on sale soon.  If you can't wait New Egg has it for $449.  It is the quad-core version.  Just make sure you are getting the quad-core version of this product.  There are a few older single core versions of this product still around.  Huge difference.  Same price.

But, Alas! after plugging the charger in for a couple of hours and seeing a battery charge symbol on the screen I elected to turn in on and________---------________ Nothing! I held-in the start button for 10, 20, 30 seconds up to a couple of minutes and one time the screen came alive with some inverted yellow triangle flashing. It then went dead again. Left the charger on over-night and again, the screen with the yellow triangle. Unplugged the charger and the screen did come on for about three minutes until I tilted it upward from the table.  I am now assuming. the battery was defective. I called Amazon and within a few minutes I was connected to great rep and with Great empathy on his part (it was my birthday when this was delivered). we agreed to trade-up for a new 32 gig model. With overnight delivery my new Galaxy note arrived exactly on time with delivery charges paid by Amazon. The new one rocks and I am overwhelmed by all the apps and I can now draw without lugging around a box full of art supplies.
My major cons for the product is there should be a led indicator light when powering up like my Dell Laptop does.
The power connector even when using the tablet case/cover. is still pinched against the table since your connector is in the middle on the bottom when the tablet is in the vertical position..

Liking it so far. Have the Note Phone and thought it would be basically the same functions, but the set up is quite different.  The Help section could definitely be better.  But they do give you a little manual. (I prefer reading than being stuck watching a 5 minute video instead of spending 15 seconds reading how to find a function.)

There is one drawback which, to me is quite problematic and could become huge over time.  I'll update this review if it does.

The power cord attachment is at the bottom of the tablet rather than the side.  So if you want to put it in a case that allows you to position it in an upright  or easel position  while charging, the Power attachment is scrunched against the desk or bottom surface, with the cord bent over.  I hope it won't ruin the connection over time and keep it from charging.

The case I bought has an opening for the charger, so that you can put it in easel position.  But if you try to just open the case, and go directly to easel position you risk bending the power attachment. To get it to work you have to detach the tablet from the cover then move it. (Separate Review).

I had an iPad 2 before, where charger is at the side.  Hope the patent office didn't give Apple the rights to a side charge, as present set up does not make sense.  Hopefully someone will come up with a case to offset the problem.
